events.title: 1900 Boxer Rebellion intervention
events.summary: An eight-nation alliance (including future NATO founders US, UK, France, Germany) militarily intervenes in China to crush a nationalist uprising, previewing Western power projection.
events.punchline: A dress rehearsal for a century of Western-led coalitions.

events.title: 1901 US Steel Corporation formed
events.summary: J.P. Morgan creates the world's first billion-dollar corporation, centralizing the industrial muscle that will power two World Wars and a Cold War.
events.punchline: Forging the arsenal of democracy, one monopoly at a time.

events.title: 1900 German Naval Law passed
events.summary: Germany dramatically expands its Imperial Navy, directly challenging British naval supremacy and forcing the UK to look for allies (like France).
events.punchline: Wilhelm II starts the arms race that his successors would lose twice.

events.title: 1900 McKinley re-elected (Roosevelt VP)
events.summary: President McKinley's victory ensures pro-industrial, expansionist foreign policy. His new VP, Theodore Roosevelt, would become a foundational figure of American global power.
events.punchline: The 'big stick' is waiting in the wings.

events.title: 1900 Planck's Quantum Theory
events.summary: Max Planck proposes quantum theory in Berlin, unknowingly starting the scientific revolution that will lead to the ultimate weapon and the nuclear deterrent at NATO's core.
events.punchline: A lecture in Berlin plants the seed for the Bomb that would end a war and define the next.

events.title: 1900 British Labour Party founded
events.summary: The formation of a party that would go on to lead Britain into NATO and be a key transatlantic partner, balancing US power within the alliance.
events.punchline: The future left-wing pillar of the Atlantic Alliance gets its start.

events.title: 1900 First Zeppelin flight
events.summary: Count von Zeppelin's rigid airship takes its first flight, pioneering a technology that would be used for bombing raids in WWI and later for transatlantic travel concepts.
events.punchline: The first step towards strategic bombing and the need to defend against it.

events.title: 1900 Hague Convention comes into force
events.summary: An early attempt to create laws of war and arms control, a principle NATO would later have to navigate constantly.
events.punchline: Writing the rulebook for the wars everyone knew were coming.

events.title: 1900 Paris Metro opens
events.summary: A symbol of modern national infrastructure and industrial organization, the kind of logistical capability that would be essential for mobilizing a continental army.
events.punchline: Building the home front, one subway line at a time.

events.title: 1900 Britain consolidates control in South Africa
events.summary: The brutal Second Boer War continues, demonstrating the scale of imperial power that would be a cornerstone of the West's global strength for the next half-century.
events.punchline: Pax Britannica: securing the resources and routes for a future Pax Americana.

events.title: 1901 Queen Victoria dies
events.summary: The end of an era. Her grandson, Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany, and her grandson, King George V of Britain, now rule Europe's two most powerful nations, setting the stage for a family feud with global consequences.
events.punchline: The matriarch of Europe dies, and her squabbling grandchildren prepare for war.

events.title: 1901 First Nobel Peace Prize awarded
events.summary: The prize goes to Henri Dunant, founder of the Red Cross, establishing an ideal of humanitarian law that NATO missions would later struggle to uphold.
events.punchline: A lofty goal set just before the most violent century in history.

events.title: 1901 Theodore Roosevelt becomes President
events.summary: After McKinley's assassination, the energetic expansionist takes office. His 'big stick' diplomacy and focus on a strong navy become permanent features of US foreign policy.
events.punchline: The architect of the American Century gets his desk.

events.title: 1901 Marconi sends first transatlantic radio signal
events.summary: The first wireless signal crosses the Atlantic from Cornwall to Newfoundland, revolutionizing communication and future command & control for a global alliance.
events.punchline: Shrinking the ocean that the Atlantic Alliance would name itself after.

events.title: 1901 US Army War College founded
events.summary: Established to teach strategy and advanced military studies, it would become a key institution for training the American officers who would lead NATO commands.
events.punchline: The school for the future SHAPE commanders opens its doors.

events.title: 1901 Hay-Pauncefote Treaty signed
events.summary: UK gives US sole right to build and defend a canal in Central America, signaling the transfer of hemispheric hegemony from Britain to the United States.
events.punchline: The 'special relationship' begins with Britain politely handing over the keys.

events.title: 1901 Socialist International meets
events.summary: European socialist parties gather, promoting international worker solidarity—an ideological challenge to the nationalist imperial order that would eventually be countered by Western unity.
events.punchline: The other internationalism: one of class, soon to be overshadowed by one of blocs.

events.title: 1901 US Navy commissions its first submarine
events.summary: USS Holland (SS-1) enters service, pioneering a weapon system that would become a critical, stealthy pillar of NATO's nuclear deterrent strategy.
events.punchline: The silent service begins, destined to carry the world's most powerful weapons.

events.title: 1901 Anglo-Japanese Alliance negotiations begin
events.summary: Britain seeks an ally in the Pacific to counter Russian and German influence, a realpolitik move that foreshadows its future strategy of building alliances against rising threats.
events.punchline: Britain's playbook: if you can't beat 'em, ally with someone who can.

events.title: 1901 President McKinley assassinated
events.summary: The murder of the US President by an anarchist highlights the emerging threat of political extremism and instability that would plague the century.
events.punchline: A violent preview of the ideological chaos that would require a defensive alliance to contain.

events.title: Treaty of Versailles
events.summary: Post-WWI settlement reshapes European borders and security.
events.punchline: Peace terms with a timer.

events.title: League of Nations formed
events.summary: First intergovernmental organization for collective security.
events.punchline: Version 0.9 of 'an attack on one...'

events.title: World War II begins
events.summary: Germany invades Poland; global war follows.
events.punchline: Patch notes for human history get ugly.

events.title: United Nations founded
events.summary: International organization for peace and cooperation is established.
events.punchline: Peace, but with a Security Council speed limiter.

events.title: Marshall Plan launched
events.summary: U.S. economic aid to rebuild Western Europe.
events.punchline: Money printer goes brrr—for democracy.

events.title: Truman Doctrine announced
events.summary: U.S. commits to support nations resisting coercion.
events.punchline: Foreign policy: 'no free lunches for bullies' edition.

events.title: Brussels Treaty signed
events.summary: Western European Union mutual defense pact among five states.
events.punchline: Logistics: 1. Block the roads. 2. Watch the skies.

events.title: North Atlantic Treaty signed
events.summary: Twelve nations create a collective defense alliance.
events.punchline: Article 5 enters the chat.

events.title: Korean War begins
events.summary: NATO coordinates strategic responses though not a NATO operation.
events.punchline: UN op, NATO brains online.

events.title: Greece and Türkiye join
events.summary: Alliance enlarges to 14 members.
events.punchline: Mediterranean DLC unlocked.

events.title: Warsaw Pact formed
events.summary: Soviet-led counter-alliance to NATO.
events.punchline: Mirror alliance equipped with 'copy strategy' perk.

events.title: West Germany joins NATO
events.summary: Integration of West Germany into Western defense.
events.punchline: From adversary to ally speedrun.

events.title: France withdraws from NATO’s integrated command
events.summary: National decision to leave integrated military structure.
events.punchline: BRB, strategic autonomy.

events.title: Harmel Report adopted
events.summary: Dual-track approach: defense + détente.
events.punchline: Peace through strength—plus coffee diplomacy.

events.title: NATO HQ moves to Brussels
events.summary: Alliance headquarters relocates from Paris to Brussels.
events.punchline: Central server migrated.

events.title: Spain joins NATO
events.summary: Membership expands on the Iberian Peninsula.
events.punchline: Tapas added to the mess hall.

events.title: CFE Treaty signed
events.summary: Conventional Armed Forces in Europe limitations agreed.
events.punchline: Cold War hardware gets a diet.

events.title: USSR dissolves
events.summary: End of the Cold War reshapes European security.
events.punchline: Final boss defeated by internal bugs.

events.title: Partnership for Peace launched
events.summary: Cooperative program with non-member states.
events.punchline: Friends list opens.

events.title: IFOR in Bosnia and Herzegovina
events.summary: NATO-led peace implementation force deployed.
events.punchline: Peacekeeping with teeth.

events.title: Kosovo air campaign
events.summary: NATO conducts Operation Allied Force.
events.punchline: No-fly meets no-chill.

events.title: Poland, Czechia, Hungary join
events.summary: First post–Cold War enlargement.
events.punchline: Eastward expansion level 1.

events.title: Article 5 invoked (9/11)
events.summary: Collective defense triggered for the first time.
events.punchline: The clause isn’t decorative.

events.title: NATO assumes ISAF command (Afghanistan)
events.summary: Stabilization mission under UN mandate.
events.punchline: Nation-building on hard mode.

events.title: Seven countries join
events.summary: Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia.
events.punchline: Enlargement speedrun PB.

events.title: Albania and Croatia join
events.summary: Further Balkan integration.
events.punchline: Adriatic secure, barbershop approved.

events.title: Libya intervention
events.summary: NATO enforces UN-authorized no-fly zone.
events.punchline: When 'air superiority' is the whole story.

events.title: Montenegro joins NATO
events.summary: Alliance grows to 29.
events.punchline: Small country, big veto power.

events.title: North Macedonia joins NATO
events.summary: Name dispute resolution enables accession.
events.punchline: One adjective later—door opens.

events.title: Finland joins NATO
events.summary: Border with Russia that actually answers back.
events.punchline: 2,600 km of 'try me'.

events.title: Sweden joins NATO
events.summary: Longstanding non-aligned state becomes member.
events.punchline: From neutrality to 'nah'.

events.title: 1905 Russian Revolution of 1905
events.summary: Widespread unrest, sparked by Bloody Sunday and war losses, forces the Tsar to create a parliament (Duma). This first crack in the Tsarist autocracy paves the way for 1917.
events.punchline: The first tremor of the earthquake that would swallow the Russian Empire.

events.title: 1905 Einstein's 'Miracle Year'
events.summary: An unknown patent clerk publishes papers on special relativity, photoelectric effect, and Brownian motion, revolutionizing physics and setting the course for the atomic age.
events.punchline: The equations that would unlock the nucleus—and unleash hell—are written in peace.

events.title: 1905 Treaty of Portsmouth ends Russo-Japanese War
events.summary: US President Theodore Roosevelt brokers peace, winning a Nobel Prize and establishing America as a global mediator and Pacific power.
events.punchline: America steps onto the world stage not with a gun, but with a negotiating table.

events.title: 1905 Norway gains full independence from Sweden
events.summary: A peaceful dissolution of the union creates a new sovereign state that will later become a founding member of NATO.
events.punchline: A peaceful divorce creates a future guardian of the North Atlantic.

events.title: 1905 First Moroccan Crisis
events.summary: Kaiser Wilhelm II visits Tangier, challenging French influence and testing the new Entente Cordiale. The crisis pushes Britain closer to France.
events.punchline: The Kaiser on a white horse, poking the Entente to see if it's real. It was.

events.title: 1905 Mutiny on the Battleship Potemkin
events.summary: Sailors of the Russian Black Sea Fleet rebel over poor conditions, a famous symbol of the revolutionary unrest sweeping Russia and a warning to all empires about troop loyalty.
events.punchline: A warship becomes a floating commune, terrifying admirals everywhere.

events.title: 1905 First formal sniper training program
events.summary: The German army establishes the first dedicated school for scoped marksmanship, recognizing the increasing importance of precision, long-range fire in modern warfare.
events.punchline: Warfare gets a scope, and the battlefield becomes exponentially more dangerous.

events.title: 1905 Karlstad Convention formalizes Norway-Sweden split
events.summary: The treaty peacefully dissolves the union between Sweden and Norway, preventing war and establishing a precedent for diplomatic conflict resolution in Scandinavia.
events.punchline: A masterclass in how to break up a kingdom without breaking any windows.

events.title: 1905 Germany launches its first U-boat, U-1
events.summary: The Imperial German Navy commissions its first submarine, a weapon that would define naval warfare in both World Wars and shape Atlantic strategy.
events.punchline: The predator that would force the Allies to invent sonar and convoys is launched.

events.title: 1905 UK Aliens Act passed
events.summary: In response to Jewish refugees fleeing pogroms, Britain passes its first law restricting immigration, reflecting a turn towards nationalism and border control.
events.punchline: The island fortress begins to draw up the drawbridge.

events.title: 1905 First radio broadcast from a ship at sea
events.summary: The US Navy experiments with transmitting music and speech from a vessel, testing the potential for ship-to-ship and ship-to-shore entertainment and communication.
events.punchline: The lonely life of a sailor gets a little less lonely, thanks to wireless.

events.title: 1905 First practical gyrocompass demonstrated
events.summary: German inventor Hermann Anschütz-Kaempfe demonstrates a compass that points to true north, unaffected by metal, revolutionizing naval navigation.
events.punchline: Ships finally know exactly where they are, which is the first step to knowing where to shoot.

events.title: 1905 Ottoman-Persian Frontier Treaty
events.summary: The Ottoman Empire and Persia (Iran) demarcate their border, creating a line that would later become the contentious Iraq-Iran border.
events.punchline: Drawing a line in the sand that would be fought over for the next 100 years.

events.title: 1905 First medical examination of pilots
events.summary: The US Army Signal Corps, anticipating the military use of aircraft, begins assessing the physical fitness of potential pilots, creating the concept of aircrew medicine.
events.punchline: Figuring out what kind of human can survive in the air, before there's an air force.

events.title: 1905 Sinn Féin political party founded
events.summary: The Irish nationalist party is established, beginning a long political and eventually paramilitary struggle that would create a neutral Republic of Ireland outside of NATO.
events.punchline: The birth of a movement that would ensure a NATO member has a neutral neighbor.

events.title: 1905 Wright Flyer III becomes first practical airplane
events.summary: The Wright brothers achieve sustained, controlled flight, making the airplane a viable technology. They immediately offer it to the US War Department.
events.punchline: The toy becomes a tool, and the sky becomes a battlefield.

events.title: 1905 First international wildlife conservation treaty
events.summary: European powers sign a treaty to protect African birds useful to agriculture, an early example of international cooperation on non-military issues.
events.punchline: Nations can agree on saving birds long before they can agree on saving themselves.

events.title: 1905 British Royal Engineers balloon corps expanded
events.summary: The UK invests more in its military balloon unit, recognizing the growing importance of aerial reconnaissance for artillery spotting and intelligence.
events.punchline: The eyes in the sky get a bigger budget.

events.title: 1905 First patent for a practical gas turbine
events.summary: Frenchman Armengaud Lemale patents a design for a continuous-combustion engine, a key step towards the jet engines that would power NATO's air supremacy.
events.punchline: The quiet birth of the scream that would define 20th-century air power.

events.title: 1905 Taft–Katsura Agreement
events.summary: The US and Japan secretly agree on spheres of influence: US acknowledges Japanese control over Korea, Japan disavows interest in the Philippines.
events.punchline: Imperial powers trade colonies like baseball cards, setting the stage for future conflict.

events.title: 1903 US backs Panamanian independence
events.summary: Theodore Roosevelt supports a revolt against Colombia to secure rights to build the Panama Canal, a masterclass in gunboat diplomacy and securing strategic global chokepoints.
events.punchline: Creating a country for a canal—the ultimate infrastructure project.

events.title: 1903 First powered, controlled flight
events.summary: The Wright Flyer takes off at Kitty Hawk, unlocking the domain of air power that would dominate 20th-century warfare and become NATO's primary battleground.
events.punchline: The first 12-second hop towards strategic bombing and air superiority.

events.title: 1903 UK Royal College of Defence Studies founded
events.summary: Established as the Imperial Defence College, it begins training senior officers and officials in grand strategy, creating the future architects of British and NATO policy.
events.punchline: The school for the masters of the chessboard opens its doors.

events.title: 1903 First complete transatlantic radio message
events.summary: Marconi establishes a commercial wireless service between US and UK, making near-instant communication across the ocean a reality—the nervous system of a future alliance.
events.punchline: Shrinking the Atlantic, one Morse code click at a time.

events.title: 1903 Russian Social Democrats split
events.summary: The party fractures into Bolsheviks (Lenin) and Mensheviks, formalizing the split that will lead to the creation of the Soviet Union—NATO's future raison d'être.
events.punchline: At a party congress in exile, the seeds of the Cold War are sown.

events.title: 1903 French Aigrette submarine launched
events.summary: The world's first diesel-powered submarine is commissioned, a key technological leap in stealth naval warfare that would define the Battle of the Atlantic.
events.punchline: Quieter, deadlier, and harder to find—the perfect naval predator is born.

events.title: 1903 US Army War College relocates to D.C.
events.summary: The key strategic institution moves to Washington D.C., placing it at the heart of political and military power, where it would shape American strategy for decades.
events.punchline: Strategy moves from the classroom to the corridors of power.

events.title: 1903 First Tour de France
events.summary: The grueling race is created to boost sales for a newspaper, but becomes a symbol of national endurance and pride—the kind of soft power that underpins alliances.
events.punchline: Building national spirit, one painful pedal stroke at a time.

events.title: 1903 Alaska Boundary Dispute settled
events.summary: An international tribunal resolves a tense US-Canada-UK border dispute, proving that Anglo-American diplomatic channels could peacefully resolve issues that might otherwise lead to conflict.
events.punchline: Neighbors learn to settle arguments without shooting—a useful skill for an alliance.

events.title: 1903 First successful diesel engine for ships
events.summary: The Russian tanker Vandal is launched, the first ship with a diesel-engine and electric transmission, revolutionizing maritime logistics and future naval propulsion.
events.punchline: Making the world smaller and the business of war more efficient.

events.title: 1903 'The Great Train Robbery' released
events.summary: This pioneering American film creates the archetype of the Western, mythologizing the expansion and individualism that defined the US character on the world stage.
events.punchline: America begins exporting its founding myth to the world.

events.title: 1903 First use of radium for therapy
events.summary: Marie Curie promotes the use of radium to treat tumors, a medical breakthrough born from the same radioactive science that would soon create the ultimate weapon.
events.punchline: The atom learns to heal, before it is taught to destroy.

events.title: 1903 IBM predecessor founded
events.summary: The Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company (CTR) is formed, which will become IBM—the company that will provide the data processing backbone for the US war effort and beyond.
events.punchline: The paperwork for future armies gets a machine to manage it.

events.title: 1903 First automobile crosses the USA
events.summary: A Packard motor car completes the two-month journey, demonstrating the potential of the internal combustion engine for mobility and future military logistics.
events.punchline: Proving a continent could be conquered without horses or railroads.

events.title: 1903 First international doping ban in sports
events.summary: The IOC discusses banning performance-enhancing drugs, an early recognition of chemical augmentation that would later have parallels in military enhancement research.
events.punchline: The quest for a superhuman soldier begins with trying to stop a superhuman cyclist.

events.title: 1903 US 'Great White Fleet' visits Mediterranean
events.summary: Roosevelt sends a battleship squadron on a global tour, a bold projection of American naval power into what had been a European-dominated sphere.
events.punchline: America's new, white business card: a fleet of battleships.

events.title: 1903 US Forest Service established
events.summary: The federal agency is created to manage natural resources, reflecting a growing understanding of strategic resource management—a national security concern.
events.punchline: Realizing that national strength requires managing more than just armies.

events.title: 1903 First international air show
events.summary: The Paris Air Show begins, immediately becoming a marketplace for military aviation technology and a stage for national competition.
events.punchline: Where future aces and arms dealers meet to make deals.

events.title: 1903 First major oil pipeline in Middle East
events.summary: The pipeline from Iranian oil fields to the Persian Gulf begins operation, inaugurating the energy infrastructure that would dictate global strategy for the next century.
events.punchline: The first vein of the lifeblood of modern warfare is tapped.

events.title: 1903 First modern World Series
events.summary: The American and National baseball leagues hold their first championship, creating a national cultural event that would help unify the American home front during future conflicts.
events.punchline: Building a national identity, one inning at a time.

events.title: 1907 Anglo-Russian Entente signed
events.summary: Britain and Russia settle their colonial disputes in Asia, completing the Triple Entente with France. The two opposing blocs of WWI are now clearly defined.
events.punchline: The final piece of the puzzle locks into place. The stage for the Great War is set.

events.title: 1911 Churchill switches Navy to oil
events.summary: UK First Lord of Admiralty Winston Churchill commits fleet to oil, not coal, tying Western security to Middle East forever.
events.punchline: The first domino for 100 years of intervention.

events.title: 1914 Archduke Franz Ferdinand assassinated
events.summary: A single bullet in Sarajevo triggers the alliance chains, plunging Europe into war.
events.punchline: The original 'Article 5' test—and it worked too well.

events.title: 1917 Zimmermann Telegram intercepted
events.summary: Germany proposes alliance with Mexico vs. US; UK intelligence leaks it, bringing America into European war.
events.punchline: Spycraft ensures US will never leave European security again.

events.title: 1919 Treaty of Versailles signed
events.summary: Victorious Allies humiliate Germany, planting seeds for WWII and the need for a permanent defensive alliance.
events.punchline: The peace treaty that guaranteed the next war.

events.title: 1922 Washington Naval Treaty
events.summary: US, UK, Japan, France, Italy agree to limit warship tonnage—first major modern arms control agreement between future Allies and foes.
events.punchline: Trying to bottle the genie of great power competition.

events.title: 1925 Locarno Treaties signed
events.summary: European powers guarantee post-WWI borders; ‘Spirit of Locarno’ offers brief hope before the darkness.
events.punchline: A collective security pact that forgot to collect security.

events.title: 1928 Kellogg-Briand Pact
events.summary: 62 nations, including USA & Germany, outlaw war as an instrument of national policy. It goes well.
events.punchline: The most ambitious and least effective ToS ever signed.

events.title: 1933 Alleged ‘Business Plot’ vs FDR
events.summary: A conspiracy theory claims wealthy industrialists tried to recruit a US Marine General to overthrow Roosevelt and install a fascist government.
events.punchline: The day American oligarchs allegedly wanted a Mussolini. (Claims unproven.)

events.title: 1935 International Business Congress
events.summary: Global industrialists meet, discussing markets and resources, unaware their factories will soon arm opposing sides of WWII.
events.punchline: Capitalism prepares to fund all sides of the coming war.

events.title: 1936 Germany reoccupies Rhineland
events.summary: Hitler violates Versailles, testing Allied resolve. France and Britain protest but do nothing.
events.punchline: The first bluff that convinced Hitler the West wouldn't fight.

events.title: 1938 Munich Agreement
events.summary: UK & France let Nazi Germany annex parts of Czechoslovakia to secure ‘peace in our time’.
events.punchline: Feeding a friend to a wolf to buy time only the wolf uses.

events.title: 1939 Nazi-Soviet Non-Aggression Pact
events.summary: Stalin and Hitler secretly agree to divide Eastern Europe, shocking Western communists and sealing WWII's start.
events.punchline: The ultimate proof that geopolitics trumps ideology every time.

events.title: 1939 WWII begins with invasion of Poland
events.summary: Germany invades from west, USSR from east. UK & France declare war, beginning the six-year struggle that will birth NATO.
events.punchline: The devastating war that made a defensive alliance inevitable.

events.title: 1940 Miracle of Dunkirk
events.summary: A massive allied evacuation saves the British army to fight another day, forging a core ‘special relationship’ between UK and US/Canada.
events.punchline: Retreat now, form NATO later.

events.title: 1940 US-UK Destroyers for Bases Deal
events.summary: Neutral USA gives UK 50 old warships in exchange for 99-year leases on British bases, a major step towards alliance.
events.punchline: America starts its journey from isolation to global cop.

events.title: 1902 Anglo-Japanese Alliance signed
events.summary: UK and Japan formalize a military pact to counter Russian expansion in Asia, proving Britain's willingness to form long-term alliances beyond Europe.
events.punchline: Wilhelm II starts the arms race that his successors would lose twice.

events.title: 1902 Philippine-American War declared over
events.summary: The US concludes a brutal counterinsurgency, solidifying its role as a Pacific power and learning counter-guerilla tactics it will use for the next century.
events.punchline: America's first lesson in the messy reality of being a global power.

events.title: 1902 Triple Alliance secretly renewed
events.summary: Germany, Austria-Hungary, and Italy quietly renew their defensive pact, further solidifying the Central Powers bloc that would trigger WWI.
events.punchline: The other team also practices its plays.

events.title: 1902 Venezuela Naval Blockade
events.summary: UK, Germany, and Italy impose a naval blockade on Venezuela to force debt repayment, demonstrating gunboat diplomacy and the kind of joint Western action that would later be institutionalized.
events.punchline: Creditors with battleships always get paid.

events.title: 1902 Alfred Thayer Mahan retires
events.summary: The influential US naval strategist, whose writings on sea power shaped the policies of Roosevelt, Wilhelm II, and other future NATO leaders, ends his active service.
events.punchline: The theorist of naval dominance hands the torch to the practitioners.

events.title: 1902 Hülsmeyer's 'Telemobiloscope'
events.summary: German inventor Christian Hülsmeyer patents a device using radio waves to detect metal objects, a primitive precursor to the radar that will be vital for NATO's air defense.
events.punchline: A German invention that the Allies would perfect to defeat Germany.

events.title: 1902 Cuba gains (limited) independence
events.summary: The US ends its military occupation but forces the Platt Amendment into the Cuban constitution, giving America the right to intervene—a model for future 'sphere of influence' policies.
events.punchline: Independence, with strings attached—a recurring theme in great power relations.

events.title: 1902 US Immigration Act expanded
events.summary: Congress makes permanent the restrictions on Chinese immigration, signaling a turn towards nationalism and a focus on shaping the country's demographic and ideological character.
events.punchline: Building a fortress America, long before it would help build a fortress Europe.

events.title: 1902 First mechanical computer demonstrated
events.summary: The 'Analytical Engine' concept is advanced, laying groundwork for the computing technology that would later give NATO its intelligence and command & control edge.
events.punchline: The first cog in the machine that would eventually break Enigma.

events.title: 1902 UK Labour Party elects first MPs
events.summary: The party wins two seats in Parliament, beginning its journey to becoming a governing party and a key pillar of the Atlantic Alliance.
events.punchline: The future left wing of NATO gets a toehold in the halls of power.

events.title: 1902 US Army creates first special ops unit
events.summary: The Corps of Scouts is formalized in the Philippines, an early experiment in specialized, irregular warfare that would evolve into the elite units integral to modern NATO operations.
events.punchline: The genesis of the tip of the spear.

events.title: 1902 International Peace Bureau wins Nobel
events.summary: The organization dedicated to pacifism wins the Nobel Peace Prize, representing the idealistic, institutional opposition to the very military alliances that were forming.
events.punchline: The dream of a war-less world wins an award, while the world prepares for war.

events.title: 1902 First dedicated anti-aircraft gun tested
events.summary: German arms manufacturer Krupp tests a modified artillery piece designed to shoot at balloons, anticipating the need for air defense decades before it became critical.
events.punchline: The first attempt to shoot into the sky, a domain that would soon dominate warfare.

events.title: 1902 Pan-American Union expands
events.summary: The forerunner to the OAS gains new members, reflecting US efforts to create a formal system of influence in its hemisphere—a regional alliance model.
events.punchline: Practicing for a military alliance by building a diplomatic one next door.

events.title: 1902 Royal Navy installs first wireless rooms
events.summary: The British fleet begins integrating Marconi's radio technology, revolutionizing naval command and control and setting the standard for all future NATO navies.
events.punchline: The admiral's voice gains global range.

events.title: 1902 Freud publishes theory on hysteria
events.summary: Sigmund Freud's work begins to gain traction, pioneering the study of the subconscious—knowledge that would later be used in psychological operations (PSYOPs) and intelligence.
events.punchline: The mind becomes a new battlefield to be mapped and manipulated.

events.title: 1902 Erskine Childers writes 'The Riddle of the Sands'
events.summary: This influential novel about a German plot to invade England popularizes the spy thriller and fuels British paranoia about German naval ambitions.
events.punchline: Fiction prepares the public's mind for the reality of enemy invasion plans.

events.title: 1902 US Newlands Reclamation Act
events.summary: Massive federal funding for irrigation projects in the West, demonstrating the US government's capacity for large-scale, nation-building projects—a skill it would later export.
events.punchline: Learning to build at home before rebuilding continents abroad.

events.title: 1902 International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) founded
events.summary: The world's first international standards organization is created, establishing a model of technical cooperation that would be essential for multinational alliances and interoperability.
events.punchline: The boring, essential work of making sure everyone's equipment plugs in together.

events.title: 1902 Aceh War intensifies
events.summary: The Dutch continue a brutal decades-long colonial war in Sumatra, a reminder of the constant low-level imperial conflicts that characterized the era before the world wars.
events.punchline: A small war on the periphery, ignored by history but perfecting tactics for larger ones.

events.title: 1904 Entente Cordiale signed
events.summary: Britain and France sign a series of agreements, resolving colonial disputes and forming the core of the alliance that would oppose the Central Powers in WWI.
events.punchline: History's greatest rivals become history's greatest allies.

events.title: 1904 Russo-Japanese War begins
events.summary: A surprise Japanese naval attack on Port Arthur shatters the myth of European invincibility and demonstrates the rise of a non-Western industrial power.
events.punchline: The first great power war of the century, and Europe isn't even invited.

events.title: 1904 US begins Panama Canal construction
events.summary: Following the engineered independence of Panama, the US begins the decade-long project to build the most strategic waterway in the world.
events.punchline: Moving mountains to move navies faster.

events.title: 1904 Design begins on HMS Dreadnought
events.summary: The British Admiralty, alarmed by German naval expansion, greenlights a revolutionary battleship design that will make all other warships obsolete and trigger a new arms race.
events.punchline: Britain resets the naval arms race to zero—and dares the world to catch up.

events.title: 1904 First successful submarine torpedo attack
events.summary: The Japanese submarine tender USS Holland (a different vessel) is sunk by a Russian submarine, proving the concept of undersea warfare.
events.punchline: The silent service proves it can kill.

events.title: 1904 Rolls-Royce Limited founded
events.summary: The luxury car company is established, which will become a critical manufacturer of piston and jet engines for Allied aircraft in both World Wars and beyond.
events.punchline: The spirit of ecstasy soon powers the spirit of victory.

events.title: 1904 First transmission of speech via radio
events.summary: The American inventor Fessenden transmits the human voice over radio waves, a crucial step towards reliable voice communication for military command.
events.punchline: Commands stop being written and start being spoken across the ether.

events.title: 1904 Robert Ripley publishes first cartoon
events.summary: The first 'Believe It or Not!' cartoon is published, beginning a franchise that would entertain millions of Allied troops and become a symbol of American pop culture.
events.punchline: Weird facts: a crucial part of military morale since 1904.

events.title: 1904 FIFA founded in Paris
events.summary: The Fédération Internationale de Football Association is established, creating the structure for the world's most popular sport—a potent tool for soft power and cultural diplomacy.
events.punchline: Organizing the world's game, long before organizing the world's defense.

events.title: 1904 USS Maine raised from Havana harbor
events.summary: The US battleship whose sinking sparked the Spanish-American War is salvaged, a symbolic act of closure for an conflict that announced America's arrival as an imperial power.
events.punchline: Raising a symbol of the war that made the US a global player.

events.title: 1904 First armored automobile demonstrated
events.summary: A French inventor adds armor and a machine gun to a car, creating the precursor to the armored fighting vehicles that would dominate future battlefields.
events.punchline: Putting a horse-less carriage in armor for the first time.

events.title: 1904 New York City Subway opens
events.summary: The first section of the IRT opens, showcasing American engineering prowess and the ability to manage vast infrastructure projects—a skill vital for mobilizing a modern nation for war.
events.punchline: Learning to move millions underground, before moving millions overseas.

events.title: 1904 First proposed use of Zeppelins for bombing
events.summary: German military strategists seriously propose using Count von Zeppelin's airships for strategic bombing campaigns, a terrifying new concept of warfare.
events.punchline: The idea of bringing war to the enemy's cities from the sky is born.

events.title: 1904 Henri Poincaré outlines Theory of Relativity
events.summary: The French mathematician publishes papers that heavily influence Einstein, contributing to the theoretical foundation that will eventually lead to nuclear physics.
events.punchline: A Frenchman lays the groundwork for a German to change the world—with energy.

events.title: 1904 USS Holland (SS-1) decommissioned
events.summary: The US Navy's first modern submarine is retired after just four years of service, highlighting the incredibly rapid pace of technological obsolescence in the new century.
events.punchline: The future arrives and is immediately replaced by a newer future.

events.title: 1904 UK Labour Party holds first conference
events.summary: The party formally establishes itself as a national political force, setting the stage for its future role in governing the UK and shaping its NATO policies.
events.punchline: The working class gets organized, eventually to help run an empire and an alliance.

events.title: 1904 First flight with hydraulic controls
events.summary: The Wright brothers incorporate hydraulic mechanisms to control their Flyer II, a key step towards making aircraft stable and controllable enough for complex military missions.
events.punchline: Turning a dangerous glider into a potential weapon.

events.title: 1904 German East Asia Squadron mobilized
events.summary: Germany's powerful naval force in the Pacific is put on alert due to the Russo-Japanese War, a show of force that reveals its global ambitions.
events.punchline: Germany's navy makes sure it has a seat at the table in the Pacific.

events.title: 1904 First transatlantic news photo transmitted
events.summary: A picture of the King of Italy is sent via cable from Rome to New York, drastically speeding up the global news cycle and public awareness of international events.
events.punchline: The world gets smaller, and public opinion becomes a factor in foreign policy.

events.title: 1904 Theodore Roosevelt wins election in his own right
events.summary: Campaigning on a platform of assertive American power, 'TR' wins a landslide victory, ensuring his progressive and interventionist policies will define the era.
events.punchline: The cowboy diplomat gets a mandate to speak softly and carry the biggest stick.

events.title: 1906 HMS Dreadnought launched
events.summary: The Royal Navy unveils its revolutionary all-big-gun battleship, rendering every other warship in the world obsolete and triggering a frantic naval arms race with Germany.
events.punchline: Britain wins the naval arms race by inventing a whole new race for everyone to run.

events.title: 1906 Algeciras Conference on Morocco
events.summary: An international conference resolves the First Moroccan Crisis, largely supporting France and demonstrating Germany's diplomatic isolation. It solidifies the Entente Cordiale.
events.punchline: Germany learns that poking the Entente only makes it stronger.

events.title: 1906 San Francisco earthquake
events.summary: A massive earthquake and fire destroy much of the city, testing American disaster response and engineering resilience—capabilities that would be crucial for recovering from wartime bombing.
events.punchline: A natural disaster provides a dress rehearsal for man-made devastation.

events.title: 1906 Reginald Fessenden makes first voice radio broadcast
events.summary: On Christmas Eve, Fessenden transmits music and speech to ships at sea, proving the potential of radio for mass communication and entertainment, key for morale.
events.punchline: The airwaves crackle to life with song, soon to carry the sounds of war.

events.title: 1906 Royal Navy forms the Home Fleet
events.summary: Britain reorganizes its naval forces into a powerful Home Fleet, specifically designed to counter the growing German High Seas Fleet in the North Sea.
events.punchline: Britain parks its most powerful toys right on Germany's doorstep.

events.title: 1906 Germany establishes first U-boat flotilla
events.summary: The Imperial German Navy groups its new submarines into a dedicated unit, beginning to develop the tactics for unrestricted submarine warfare.
events.punchline: The wolfpack gets its first den.

events.title: 1906 First International Radiotelegraph Convention
events.summary: Nations meet to establish common rules for radio communication, particularly for maritime safety. This early standardization is crucial for future allied interoperability.
events.punchline: The world agrees on how to say 'SOS' before it needs to.

events.title: 1906 Picasso begins 'Les Demoiselles d'Avignon'
events.summary: Pablo Picasso starts his revolutionary painting, shattering traditional perspective and helping to invent Cubism—a cultural upheaval mirroring the coming political fragmentation of Europe.
events.punchline: Art breaks into pieces, just like the old world order.

events.title: 1906 First tests of bombsights from airships
events.summary: The German military experiments with aiming and dropping dummy bombs from Zeppelins, developing the tactics for strategic bombing.
events.punchline: Practicing to make sure bombs fall on the right city.

events.title: 1906 Persian Constitutional Revolution
events.summary: Iran establishes a parliament (Majlis) and a constitution, limiting the Shah's power. The event draws in Russian and British interests, beginning decades of great power meddling.
events.punchline: A parliament is born in a country that would become a Cold War battleground.

events.title: 1906 US Army tests first long-distance truck convoy
events.summary: The Army drives four trucks from Vermont to Missouri, assessing the automobile's potential to replace horses and wagons for logistics—the dawn of mechanized supply.
events.punchline: The horse sees its replacement driving down the road.

events.title: 1906 UK Liberal Party wins landslide election
events.summary: The party wins a massive majority, leading to major social reforms and increased naval spending to counter Germany, setting the domestic context for Britain's entry into WWI.
events.punchline: Voters choose butter, and the government immediately orders more guns.

events.title: 1906 First successful submarine rescue
events.summary: The crew of the sunk French submarine 'Farfadet' is rescued using new technology, an early step in developing procedures that would be vital for NATO's submarine forces.
events.punchline: Learning how to get sailors back from the iron coffin.

events.title: 1906 Finland grants women full political rights
events.summary: The autonomous Grand Duchy of Finland becomes the first European nation to give women both the right to vote and to stand for election, a progressive social step.
events.punchline: A future NATO member leads the way on equality, 40 years before the alliance exists.

events.title: 1906 US Pure Food and Drug Act passed
events.summary: Spurred by muckraking journalism, this law begins federal regulation of food and medicine, demonstrating a growing, capable federal bureaucracy.
events.punchline: The government learns to protect its citizens' health, a skill needed for their security.

events.title: 1906 First widespread use of motorized ambulances
events.summary: Cities begin replacing horse-drawn ambulances with motorized ones, significantly improving response times and medical outcomes—a critical development for battlefield medicine.
events.punchline: Saving lives gets a lot faster, just in time for a war that would need it.

events.title: 1906 Major volcanic eruptions in Caribbean
events.summary: Eruptions on Martinique and St. Vincent cause widespread destruction, testing colonial disaster response and reminding powers of the vulnerability of their overseas assets.
events.punchline: Nature reminds empires that their possessions are not always peaceful.

events.title: 1906 Berlin Revised Copyright Convention
events.summary: Nations update international copyright law, protecting intellectual property across borders—a system that would later protect everything from propaganda films to weapons designs.
events.punchline: Figuring out how to own an idea, before those ideas become superweapons.

events.title: 1906 First speed bump installed
events.summary: The American town of Chatham, New Jersey, installs the first documented 'speed bump' to control the new menace of the automobile—a low-tech solution to a high-tech problem.
events.punchline: The first attempt to control the machine that would mechanize war.

events.title: 1906 Theodore Roosevelt wins Nobel Peace Prize
events.summary: Awarded for mediating the end of the Russo-Japanese War, it cements the US President's image as a global statesman and America's role as a rising peacekeeper.
events.punchline: The 'big stick' diplomat gets a peace prize—the ultimate soft power flex.

events.title: 1907 Second Hague Convention
events.summary: 46 nations meet to further expand the laws of war, attempting to humanize a conflict everyone sees coming. Rules for aerial bombing and naval warfare are discussed for the first time.
events.punchline: Writing a rulebook for the apocalypse, hoping someone will read it.

events.title: 1907 First manned helicopter flight
events.summary: French inventor Paul Cornu lifts off the ground for 20 seconds in a twin-rotor machine, demonstrating the potential for vertical flight that would later revolutionize military logistics and medevac.
events.punchline: The first wobbling step towards the whirring sound of rescue and assault.

events.title: 1907 New Zealand becomes a Dominion
events.summary: The country gains greater independence within the British Empire, solidifying its status as a loyal ally that would contribute significantly to both World Wars.
events.punchline: Another ANZAC nation steps up, ready to answer the call from the other side of the world.

events.title: 1907 First International Psychoanalytical Congress
events.summary: Freud's followers meet to formalize his theories. The study of the human psyche would later be used in intelligence, propaganda, and understanding the stress of combat.
events.punchline: The mind becomes a new frontier to be analyzed, manipulated, and broken.

events.title: 1907 US 'Great White Fleet' begins world tour
events.summary: President Roosevelt sends 16 gleaming white battleships on a 14-month global voyage, a massive demonstration of American naval power and its arrival as a global force.
events.punchline: America's coming-out party: an armada of battleships doing a victory lap around the planet.

events.title: 1907 First electric washing machine sold
events.summary: The Hurley Machine Company markets the 'Thor,' beginning the electrification of the home and freeing up labor—a small part of the societal shift that would mobilize entire economies for war.
events.punchline: Automating the laundry, one step towards automating the factory floor.

events.title: 1907 First commercial transatlantic radio service
events.summary: Marconi's company opens a public wireless telegraph link between Ireland and Canada, making near-instant communication across the ocean a commercial reality.
events.punchline: The nervous system of the future Atlantic Alliance gets its first commercial wire.

events.title: 1907 Bakelite invented
events.summary: Leo Baekeland patents the first fully synthetic plastic. This durable material would soon be used in everything from electrical insulation to weapon components.
events.punchline: The age of plastic begins, and soon nothing of war will be without it.

events.title: 1907 French Army acquires its first aircraft
events.summary: The French military purchases a Wright brothers biplane, becoming one of the first armed forces to officially adopt the airplane, recognizing its potential for reconnaissance.
events.punchline: The French army looks to the sky and sees the future of intelligence.

events.title: 1907 Anglo-Russian Convention divides Persia
events.summary: As part of their entente, Britain and Russia agree to divide Persia into spheres of influence, a classic act of imperial realpolitik that would fuel regional resentment for decades.
events.punchline: Two empires draw a line through a third country, as if it were their own.

events.title: 1907 International Scout Movement founded
events.summary: Robert Baden-Powell holds the first Scout camp on Brownsea Island, creating a global youth movement that would instill outdoor skills and patriotism in future generations of soldiers.
events.punchline: Teaching boys to be prepared, for adventures and eventually for trenches.

events.title: 1907 First international air race held
events.summary: The Gordon Bennett Cup for airplanes is held, driving rapid technological innovation in aviation as competitors seek an edge in speed and reliability.
events.punchline: Racing for a trophy today, building a fighter plane tomorrow.

events.title: 1907 First Mother's Day observance
events.summary: Anna Jarvis holds a memorial for her mother in West Virginia, starting a campaign for a national holiday that would become a cornerstone of home front morale in wartime.
events.punchline: Celebrating the people who would send their sons off to war.

events.title: 1907 UK debates National Health Insurance
events.summary: The Liberal government lays the groundwork for social welfare programs, understanding that a healthy population is a strong population, both for industry and for war.
events.punchline: Investing in the human capital that would man the factories and the front lines.

events.title: 1907 First experiments with aerial artillery spotting
events.summary: The US Army Signal Corps experiments with using kites and balloons to direct artillery fire, a revolutionary concept that would make the cannon infinitely more deadly.
events.punchline: Giving the big guns eyes from the heavens.

events.title: 1907 German SPD becomes largest party in Reichstag
events.summary: The Social Democratic Party wins the most seats, representing the rise of organized labor and socialist politics that deeply worried the conservative German establishment.
events.punchline: The Kaiser's government faces its greatest threat not from abroad, but from its own workers.

events.title: 1907 Haber-Bosch process developed
events.summary: Fritz Haber and Carl Bosch develop a method to synthesize ammonia from air, creating artificial fertilizer. This same process would later be used to make explosives.
events.punchline: Learning to feed millions, and soon after, to blow millions to pieces.

events.title: 1907 First major oil strike in Persia
events.summary: The Anglo-Persian Oil Company (later BP) strikes oil in commercial quantities, transforming the geopolitical importance of the Middle East for the next century.
events.punchline: The liquid that would fuel the century's wars is found in the desert.

events.title: 1907 Bankers' Panic
events.summary: A run on banks in New York triggers a national financial crisis, ultimately leading to the creation of the Federal Reserve System to stabilize the US economy—a critical step for funding future wars.
events.punchline: The economy crashes, forcing America to build a system robust enough to bankroll a world war.

events.title: 1908 Young Turk Revolution
events.summary: A coup in the Ottoman Empire restores the constitution and parliament, modernizing the sick man of Europe and briefly aligning it with Germany, altering the Balkan balance of power.
events.punchline: The dying empire gets a jolt of adrenaline, choosing the wrong friends for its final act.

events.title: 1908 Austria-Hungary annexes Bosnia & Herzegovina
events.summary: The Dual Monarchy formally absorbs the territory, enraging Serbia and Russia and bringing Europe to the brink of war. It's a major step on the path to 1914.
events.punchline: A land grab in the Balkans that tightens the spring of European war.

events.title: 1908 First passenger flight
events.summary: Wilbur Wright takes a mechanic, Charles Furnas, on a flight at Kitty Hawk, proving the airplane could carry more than a pilot—a key step towards bombers and transport planes.
events.punchline: The sky is no longer a solo experience; it can now be a shared mission.

events.title: 1908 Ford Model T introduced
events.summary: Henry Ford's affordable, assembly-line car begins to mobilize America, revolutionizing industry, society, and laying the groundwork for the mechanization of warfare.
events.punchline: Putting a nation on wheels, soon to put an army on tracks.

events.title: 1908 UK establishes Imperial General Staff
events.summary: Britain creates a permanent, professional body to coordinate military strategy across its global empire, a precursor to a unified allied command structure.
events.punchline: Organizing the defense of an empire, one memo at a time.

events.title: 1908 Tunguska Event
events.summary: A massive explosion flattens 800 square miles of Siberian forest. The mysterious blast, likely a meteorite, fuels speculation and shows the vulnerability of the planet.
events.punchline: A reminder from the cosmos that existential threats don't always come from other nations.

events.title: 1908 First machine gun fired from an airplane
events.summary: US Lt. Thomas Selfridge fires a rifle from a powered aircraft, conducting the first tests of airborne weaponry and envisioning the future of aerial combat.
events.punchline: The sky ceases to be a neutral space and becomes a potential battlefield.

events.title: 1908 Bulgaria declares independence
events.summary: Taking advantage of the Young Turk revolution, Bulgaria breaks free from Ottoman suzerainty, further destabilizing the Balkans and adding another player to the volatile region.
events.punchline: Another nation is born in the powder keg of Europe.

events.title: 1908 Crete unifies with Greece
events.summary: The Cretan parliament declares union with Greece, a move that strengthens Greece and further weakens the Ottoman hold on the Mediterranean.
events.punchline: Greece gains an island, and a future NATO member grows a little stronger.

events.title: 1908 Lumière brothers market Autochrome
events.summary: The first commercially successful color photography process is introduced, adding a new, powerful dimension to intelligence, propaganda, and documenting war.
events.punchline: The world gains color, and soon war will be documented in vivid, bloody detail.

events.title: 1908 International Criminal Police Congress
events.summary: Police officials from across Europe meet to discuss cooperation against anarchists and criminals, an early model of international law enforcement collaboration.
events.punchline: Cops without borders meet, long before soldiers without borders.

events.title: 1908 Shaw's 'Major Barbara' premieres
events.summary: George Bernard Shaw's play critiques the morality of the arms industry and charity, sparking public debate about the intersection of capitalism, war, and ethics.
events.punchline: Asking uncomfortable questions about who profits from violence, a century early.

events.title: 1908 US Army establishes first permanent radio station
events.summary: The Signal Corps sets up a station at Fort Myer, creating the nucleus of a military communications network that would span the globe.
events.punchline: The US Army gets its first permanent voice, crackling over the airwaves.

events.title: 1908 First military psychology research
events.summary: German military physicians begin systematic studies on the mental strain of military service, pioneering the field of combat stress research.
events.punchline: The military begins to study the breaking point of the human mind, not just the body.

events.title: 1908 Oil discovered in Iran in commercial quantity
events.summary: The first great Middle Eastern oil strike is made, fundamentally altering the region's geopolitical significance for the British Empire and the world.
events.punchline: Black gold changes everything. The great game becomes an oil game.

events.title: 1908 First around-the-world automobile race
events.summary: Six cars leave New York in a grueling race across continents, testing the limits of automotive endurance and showcasing the need for global infrastructure.
events.punchline: Proving a machine could circumnavigate the Earth, a necessary step for global war.

events.title: 1908 Eleftherios Venizelos enters Greek politics
events.summary: The future Prime Minister who would lead Greece through the Balkan Wars and WWI, and be a key Western ally, is elected to the Greek parliament.
events.punchline: A pro-Western statesman rises in Athens, ready to steer his country into the coming storms.

events.title: 1908 First successful hydroplane tested
events.summary: The Frenchman Henri Fabre designs a successful seaplane, opening the possibility for naval aviation and aircraft carriers.
events.punchline: An airplane learns to swim, and navies around the world take notice.

events.title: 1908 UK Old-Age Pensions Act
events.summary: The British government introduces the first state pensions, a landmark social reform that strengthens the social contract and national stability.
events.punchline: A government ensures its citizens are cared for in old age, ensuring their loyalty in youth.

events.title: 1908 First US National Wildlife Refuge
events.summary: President Roosevelt establishes the National Bison Range, demonstrating federal power to conserve resources—a concept that extends to strategic resource management.
events.punchline: Saving the buffalo, practicing how to manage a nation's precious assets.

events.title: 1909 Louis Blériot crosses the English Channel
events.summary: The French aviator flies from Calais to Dover in 37 minutes, proving aircraft could overcome a major strategic barrier and stunning British military planners.
events.punchline: The Channel is no longer a moat. Britain's island security is breached by a wooden biplane.

events.title: 1909 Young Turk Counter-Revolution
events.summary: A conservative uprising against the new government is crushed by the Young Turks, solidifying their power and pushing the Ottoman Empire further into the German sphere.
events.punchline: The modernizers win, but choose the wrong imperial patron for their new-old empire.

events.title: 1909 Peary claims reach of North Pole
events.summary: American explorer Robert Peary allegedly reaches the North Pole, a feat of endurance that also staked a symbolic claim in the strategically important Arctic.
events.punchline: Planting a flag at the top of the world, a future arena for nuclear submarines.

events.title: 1909 German Naval Scare in Britain
events.summary: Fears of accelerated German battleship construction trigger a panic in the UK, leading to public cries for 'We want eight and we won't wait!' dreadnoughts.
events.punchline: Public opinion forces the Admiralty's hand: the naval arms race goes into overdrive.

events.title: 1909 Freud lectures in the United States
events.summary: Sigmund Freud and Carl Jung give a seminal series of lectures at Clark University, introducing psychoanalysis to America and influencing future psychological operations.
events.punchline: The unconscious mind gets a passport and enters American academia.

events.title: 1909 US Army buys its first airplane
events.summary: After successful trials, the Signal Corps purchases the Wright Military Flyer for $30,000, officially launching American military aviation.
events.punchline: The US military writes a check and gets a air force. (It only has one plane.)

events.title: 1909 Bosnia Annexation Crisis resolved
events.summary: Under German threat, Russia and Serbia are forced to diplomatically accept Austria-Hungary's annexation of Bosnia. The humiliation fuels Slavic nationalism and Russian rearmament.
events.punchline: Germany backs its ally to a victory that only makes the next war more certain.

events.title: 1909 North Pole discovery disputed
events.summary: Frederick Cook claims he reached the Pole first. The bitter public controversy undermines the achievement and distracts from serious geopolitical issues.
events.punchline: Two explorers argue over a frozen point while Europe prepares to argue over continents.

events.title: 1909 Grande Semaine d'Aviation de la Champagne
events.summary: The first major international air meet in Reims, France, becomes a showcase of aviation technology and a de facto arms fair for European powers.
events.punchline: A week-long party in Champagne where the main attraction is the future of warfare.

events.title: 1909 NAACP founded
events.summary: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is established, beginning a long struggle for civil rights that would eventually see Black soldiers fight for a democracy that denied them rights at home.
events.punchline: The fight for the soul of America intensifies, just as America prepares to save the world.

events.title: 1909 UK Old Age Pensions begin
events.summary: The first payments are made under the 1908 Act, a cornerstone of the British welfare state that strengthens social cohesion before the coming trial.
events.punchline: A nation commits to caring for its elderly, ensuring unity when it asks its youth to fight.

events.title: 1909 'SOS' becomes international distress signal
events.summary: The Berlin Radiotelegraphic Convention formally adopts '... --- ...' (SOS) as the universal distress call, standardizing a critical element of maritime and later, military communication.
events.punchline: The world agrees on a universal cry for help, just before it will need one.

events.title: 1909 Hotchkiss Portative demonstrated
events.summary: The French Hotchkiss company unveils a lighter, portable machine gun, a precursor to the light machine guns that would become essential squad-level weapons.
events.punchline: The wall of fire becomes mobile, and the infantryman's job changes forever.

events.title: 1909 Secret talks begin for Balkan League
events.summary: Serbia and Bulgaria start negotiating a secret alliance aimed at pushing the Ottoman Empire out of Europe, setting the stage for the Balkan Wars.
events.punchline: In the shadow of the bigger powers, smaller ones plot to redraw their own map.

events.title: 1909 Ford Model T production ramps up
events.summary: The moving assembly line is perfected, beginning the era of mass-produced automobiles. The industrial lessons learned here will be applied to tanks and planes.
events.punchline: Henry Ford invents the system that will churn out the tools of victory.

events.title: 1909 Stolypin's agrarian reforms accelerate
events.summary: Russian PM Pyotr Stolypin pushes land reforms to create a class of independent farmers, a last desperate attempt to modernize the Russian economy and avoid revolution.
events.punchline: Trying to fix the foundation of the Russian Empire as the walls are cracking.

events.title: 1909 France opens first military aviation school
events.summary: The École d'Aviation Militaire is established at Versailles, creating the world's first institution dedicated to training military pilots.
events.punchline: The first school for the knights of the air opens its doors.

events.title: 1909 Ballinger-Pinchot controversy begins
events.summary: A scandal erupts over corruption in the US Department of the Interior, testing the progressive reforms of the era and the integrity of the federal government.
events.punchline: America's government proves it can be corrupt, even as it prepares for global leadership.

events.title: 1909 Germany takes delivery of first Zeppelin for military use
events.summary: The German Army accepts its first rigid airship, Z I, beginning the integration of these giant craft into its reconnaissance and bombing plans.
events.punchline: The sky over Germany gets a new, giant, explosive-filled resident.

events.title: 1909 First National Woman's Day observed in US
events.summary: The Socialist Party of America organizes the event, a forerunner to International Women's Day, highlighting the growing movement for suffrage and rights.
events.punchline: Half the population demands a voice, just as the world is about to demand their sacrifice.

events.title: 1910 Japan annexes Korea
events.summary: The Japan-Korea Annexation Treaty formally incorporates Korea into the Japanese Empire, a major step in Japanese expansionism that would later concern future Western allies.
events.punchline: The Rising Sun flag flies over the Hermit Kingdom, a preview of Pacific conquests to come.

events.title: 1910 Union of South Africa formed
events.summary: The British colonies of the Cape, Natal, Transvaal, and Orange River are unified into a single dominion, creating a key Commonwealth ally with a formidable military tradition.
events.punchline: From Boer War enemies to a unified dominion that will stand with Britain in two world wars.

events.title: 1910 First mid-air collision
events.summary: Two aircraft collide over Milan, Italy, highlighting the new dangers of the air and the urgent need for air traffic control and military coordination protocols.
events.punchline: The sky, once infinite, suddenly feels very crowded and very dangerous.

events.title: 1910 Portuguese monarchy overthrown
events.summary: A revolution establishes the First Portuguese Republic, destabilizing the oldest alliance in Europe (the Anglo-Portuguese Alliance) and creating a volatile political situation.
events.punchline: Britain's oldest ally gets a new government, and a new set of problems.

events.title: 1910 First radio broadcast of a live performance
events.summary: Enrico Caruso is broadcast live from the Metropolitan Opera in New York, demonstrating radio's power for mass culture and its potential for propaganda.
events.punchline: The airwaves carry opera today, will carry Churchill's speeches tomorrow.

events.title: 1910 Sir Edward Grey's ominous warning
events.summary: The British Foreign Secretary observes the naval arms race and remarks, 'The lamps are going out all over Europe; we shall not see them lit again in our lifetime.'
events.punchline: A statesman sees the coming darkness, four years before the switch is flipped.

events.title: 1910 First aircraft launch from a ship
events.summary: American pilot Eugene Ely takes off from a makeshift platform on the USS Birmingham, proving the concept of what would become the aircraft carrier.
events.punchline: A biplane on a cruiser: the humble birth of a weapon that would rule the seas.

events.title: 1910 Qing Dynasty abolishes slavery
events.summary: In one of its last acts, the crumbling imperial government outlaws slavery, a reform that does little to stop the revolutionary fervor sweeping the country.
events.punchline: An empire tries to reform itself on its deathbed.

events.title: 1910 First police radio system tested
events.summary: The US police department in Berkeley, California, experiments with radio communication in patrol cars, pioneering technology for command and control.
events.punchline: Cops get radios, a technology that will soon be used to coordinate entire armies.

events.title: 1910 Halley's Comet causes mass hysteria
events.summary: The comet's return, and claims its tail would poison the atmosphere, lead to widespread panic, showing the power of media and public irrationality—a lesson for future propaganda.
events.punchline: The world fears death from the sky, not yet realizing the threat would be man-made.

events.title: 1910 First Balkan Socialist Conference
events.summary: Socialist parties from across the Balkans meet, attempting to foster working-class solidarity over the nationalism that was tearing the region apart. They fail.
events.punchline: An attempt to unite by class in a region destined to be divided by nation.

events.title: 1910 UK Parliament Act crisis begins
events.summary: A major constitutional crisis erupts as the House of Lords rejects the People's Budget, leading to a clash that will curtail the Lords' power and reshape British democracy.
events.punchline: The British aristocracy fights its last stand against democracy, and loses.

events.title: 1910 France sends gunboat to Agadir
events.summary: In a show of force following a tribal revolt, France dispatches a warship to the Moroccan port of Agadir, a prelude to a much larger crisis the following year.
events.punchline: A small gunboat in a Moroccan port sets the stage for a very big German reaction.

events.title: 1910 First electric dishwasher sold
events.summary: The Walker brothers produce a commercially successful electric dishwasher, part of the wave of domestic electrification that would change the workforce and the home front.
events.punchline: A machine to wash dishes, a small step towards freeing labor for the factory floor.

events.title: 1910 Ballets Russes stuns Paris
events.summary: Diaghilev's Russian ballet company premieres Scheherazade in Paris, causing a sensation and creating a cultural bridge between Russia and the West.
events.punchline: Art from St. Petersburg captivates Paris, weaving a cultural thread in the Entente.

events.title: 1910 Boy Scouts of America founded
events.summary: Inspired by Baden-Powell, the BSA is incorporated, instilling outdoor skills, patriotism, and discipline in American youth—values that would define a generation of soldiers.
events.punchline: Be Prepared: the motto for a million future GIs.

events.title: 1910 First use of aircraft for colonial policing
events.summary: The Italian army uses aircraft for reconnaissance during operations in Libya, a early demonstration of air power's role in counterinsurgency.
events.punchline: The airplane gets its first job: watching rebellious subjects from the sky.

events.title: 1910 Einstein becomes full professor
events.summary: The theoretical physicist is appointed to a chair at the German Charles-Ferdinand University in Prague, giving him more resources to develop his world-changing ideas.
events.punchline: The man who will unlock the atom gets a pay raise and a better lab.

events.title: 1910 First official Mother's Day observed in US
events.summary: West Virginia becomes the first state to recognize the holiday, beginning a tradition that would become a key part of home front morale and propaganda.
events.punchline: A holiday for the women who would be asked to sacrifice their sons for their country.

events.title: 1910 A.V. Roe and Company founded
events.summary: Alliott Verdon Roe establishes one of the first aircraft manufacturing companies in the UK, which will become Avro—a legendary builder of British bombers like the Lancaster.
events.punchline: A small workshop is founded, destined to build the machines that would burn German cities.

events.title: 1911 Agadir Crisis (Second Moroccan Crisis)
events.summary: Germany sends the gunboat Panther to Agadir, Morocco, to challenge French influence. The move backfires, solidifying the Entente Cordiale and humiliating Germany.
events.punchline: Germany tries to flex, but only succeeds in pushing Britain and France closer together.

events.title: 1911 Italo-Turkish War begins
events.summary: Italy declares war on the Ottoman Empire and invades Libya, using aircraft and airships in combat for the first time and further destabilizing the Balkans.
events.punchline: A European power uses a dying empire for target practice, and the airplane gets its first taste of war.

events.title: 1911 Xinhai Revolution begins
events.summary: An uprising in Wuchang triggers the collapse of the Qing Dynasty, ending 2,000 years of imperial rule and plunging China into decades of warlordism and civil war.
events.punchline: An ancient empire falls, creating a power vacuum that will suck in the world for a century.

events.title: 1911 First aerial bomb dropped in combat
events.summary: An Italian pilot drops a Cipelli grenade on Turkish positions in Libya, marking the birth of strategic bombing and forever changing the nature of warfare.
events.punchline: Death arrives from above, delivered by a pilot leaning out of his cockpit.

events.title: 1911 Parliament Act becomes law
events.summary: The UK House of Lords is stripped of its power to veto money bills, a decisive victory for the House of Commons that consolidates British democracy before its great test.
events.punchline: The people's representatives finally win centuries of power struggle, just in time to lead the nation to war.

events.title: 1911 Rutherford discovers the atomic nucleus
events.summary: Ernest Rutherford's gold foil experiment reveals the structure of the atom, a fundamental breakthrough that will ultimately lead to the harnessing of nuclear energy.
events.punchline: A scientist in Manchester peers into the heart of matter and unlocks a power that will define the century.

events.title: 1911 First non-stop London to Paris flight
events.summary: Pierre Prier completes the direct flight, demonstrating the reliability of aircraft and shrinking the perceived distance between future Allied capitals.
events.punchline: The Channel is crossed without a second thought, linking two future allies by air.

events.title: 1911 US financial panic and trust-busting
events.summary: Economic uncertainty and President Taft's aggressive antitrust prosecutions shake Wall Street, testing the resilience of the US economy ahead of global conflict.
events.punchline: The government breaks up monopolies, trying to control the economic forces it will soon need to command for war.

events.title: 1911 First official airmail flight
events.summary: Henri Péquet carries mail from Allahabad to Naini in India, proving the practicality of air transport for logistics and communication.
events.punchline: The first letters fly, a humble beginning for the air supply chains that will sustain armies.

events.title: 1911 Amundsen reaches South Pole
events.summary: The Norwegian explorer beats Robert Scott to the Pole, a triumph of planning and endurance that showcased Scandinavian prowess on the global stage.
events.punchline: A small nation plants its flag at the bottom of the world, a sign of quiet competence.

events.title: 1911 US Navy launches its first amphibious aircraft
events.summary: The Curtiss A-1 Triad becomes the US Navy's first aircraft, capable of taking off from and landing on both water and land.
events.punchline: The US Navy gets its wings, and they can get wet.

events.title: 1911 Mexican Revolution overthrows Díaz
events.summary: President Porfirio Díaz is forced to resign and flee to France, beginning a decade of brutal civil war on the US southern border.
events.punchline: A nation descends into chaos right next door, a persistent problem for American security.

events.title: 1911 First machine gun mounted on an airplane
events.summary: US Army Lt. Jacob Fickel successfully fires a machine gun from a moving aircraft, proving the concept of the armed fighter plane.
events.punchline: The flying machine officially becomes a weapons platform.

events.title: 1911 Standard Oil broken up
events.summary: The US Supreme Court orders the dissolution of John D. Rockefeller's monopoly, fracturing the world's largest company and reshaping the global oil industry.
events.punchline: The government shatters the world's most powerful corporation, just as oil becomes the lifeblood of strategy.

events.title: 1911 First radio-controlled aircraft
events.summary: Inventor Wilson Greathead demonstrates a model aircraft guided by radio waves, a primitive precursor to drones and guided missiles.
events.punchline: The first unmanned flight, a tiny model of the robotic warfare to come.

events.title: 1911 UK National Insurance Act
events.summary: David Lloyd George's landmark legislation provides health and unemployment insurance, creating a social safety net that would help stabilize British society through coming wars.
events.punchline: The state takes responsibility for its citizens' well-being, ensuring a healthier, more loyal population for the trials ahead.

events.title: 1911 British Army establishes wireless companies
events.summary: The Royal Engineers form dedicated wireless companies, integrating radio technology into the army's command structure for the first time.
events.punchline: The British Army gets a new voice, one that crackles through the ether.

events.title: 1911 José Raúl Capablanca rises to fame
events.summary: The Cuban chess prodigy begins his legendary career, his style of clear, strategic dominance mirroring the kind of thinking that would later define Cold War strategy.
events.punchline: A master of the 64-square board emerges, a metaphor for the grandmasters of geopolitics to come.

events.title: 1911 First electric starter for automobiles
events.summary: Cadillac introduces the electric starter, eliminating the dangerous hand crank and making cars accessible to everyone—a key step towards mass mobilization.
events.punchline: The car becomes easy to start, and America becomes easy to mobilize.

events.title: 1911 Mona Lisa stolen from the Louvre
events.summary: The painting is stolen by an Italian patriot, causing an international scandal and demonstrating the vulnerability of even the most secure institutions.
events.punchline: A man walks out with the world's most famous painting, a lesson in security and audacity.

events.title: 1912 Balkan League secret treaty signed
